Students In These Departments Entering Next Year Must Pay $250.
Students Already Enrolled
Not Affected.

The logical step was to raise the
tuition fee, not only because the
university is losing money in
teaching its students, but because
the abnormally large enrollments
of the last two years have made
some method of limiting the size
of the student-body essential.
From all over the country have
come reports of the extraordinarily overcrowded conditions of
American universities, and many
of these institutions have adopted
the expedient of increasing their
charges as the most obvious and
logical means of checking the unexpected flood of students. Harvard announced the increase of
her rates to $250 the day before
Hopkins took similar action.
The increase at Johns Hopkins
includes only the two undergraduate departments, arts and
sciences, and engineering, and will
not affect the fees for graduate
and medical students, who are
charged, respectively, $150 and

DR. WOOD GIVES LECTURE
ON VIOLET RAY
Large Body of Students Present.
Many Interesting Phenomena
Explained.

So attractive was the mere announcement of a lecture by Dr.
Robert W. Wood, one of Hopkins'
most famous scientists, on the subject with which his name is everywhere linked, that one of the largest crowds of the year besieged
the doors of the lecture-room in
the Mechanical Engineering Building, necessitating a division of the
audience into two relays. Dr.
Wood very kindly consented to
this plan, not objecting to the inconvenience of giving a continuous
performance a la movies.
Dr. Wood plunged immediately
into the explanation of how he had
utilized the hitherto unrelated
phenomena connected with the
viol-ray emanations f o r producing a highly valuable method
of invisible night signalling on a
practical engineering scale. In
clear, simple language he sketched
the theory and development of
the ultra-violet ray lamp and receiver used by our navy during the
war.
Before giving his audience a
chance to see for themselves the
weird effects of his invention, the
lecturer explained what would
happen. The _violet rays would
cause teeth and eyes to fluoresce,
and in the case of those close
enough to the lamp the skin and
nails would also shine.
Then the room lights were
turned down, and out of the darkness somewhere down in front
there danced and faded a beautiful blue light, weak and retiring
as a will o' the wisp at first, but
gradually increasing in steadiness
to the time when a soft blue haze
began to settle before the eyes of
the mystified observers. The nian
in the front row who turned away
from the lamp when the haze appeared only to see the teeth of his
friend leaping out at him like the
advertisement of a painless dentist may be pardoned if he dropped
his books. Indeed, if Dr. Wood
had not warned the assembly
ahead of time that the blue haze
was merely an effect of the fluorescing of the eyes under the violet
rays, many a man would have left
the hall.
After he had finished exhibiting
many of the peculiarities of his
pet, Dr. Wood allowed the men to
come down a few at a time to get.
a close view of the phenomena. It
was, indeed, a rare opportunity.
and no man who witnessed the
demonstration is liable to forget
it for a long time.

ELECTRICAL CLUB MAKES
INTERESTING CHANGE
IN WORK
Solutions of Current Problems Planned.
Melvin Fuld to Speak March
11 on Motor Troubles.

On Friday, February 25, Mr.
Wm. S. Weikle gave the Hopkins
Electrical Club a very interesting
illustrated lecture on "The Development of Low Head Plants." He
told of the rehabilitation of many
old power plants, the efficiency being greatly increased by the installation of new equipment in conjunction with the water turbines
already operating. A general discussion followed the talk and Mr.
Weikle answered questions pertaining to his subject.
The club has set aside part of
the time of its meetings for the
solution of current problems arising in the electrical engineering
course and it is believed that this
feature of the program will prove
very beneficial to all the members.
Difficulties resulting from the previous week's work will be cleared
up and advance theory explained,
so that those attending the meetings will be at an advantage in
that they will be familiar with
the new work as it is taken up.
The organization, though only
a few weeks old, has made rapid
progress, its membership now, including some 25 seniors, juniors,
and a few sophomores.
The next meeting will be held
on Friday, March 11, when Mr.
Melvin Fuld will talk on "Minor
Motor Troubles and Their Remedies." An interesting program
is promised and visitors are always welcome.

SCHEDULE OF HULLABALOO
PICTURES FOR THIS WEEK.

The Hullabaloo staff photographer will take pictures of Seniors
at the Barn today.(Tuesday) from
12.30 to 2.00 P. M. This is the last
day on which these snapshots may
be taken. This is also the last
week in which individual Senior
pictures can be taken at Yatt's
studio, 313 North Charles street.
The schedule of groups for the
week is as follows:
TUESDAY.
12.20—Senior class—on steps of
Gilman Hall.
12.30—R. 0. T. C.—student officers.
12.30—R. 0. T. C. regular
army officers—steps of Gilman.
12.45—Freshman class—in bowl
in front of Hopkins Club.
WEDNESDAY:
12.20—Junior class—in bowl.
12.35—Sophomore class.
1.00—Orchestra in the Barn.
THURSDAY, ill Room 109, M. E.:

staff.

Council.

With the opening game only
three weeks off Coach Armstrong
has been busily engaged during
the past week with the battery
candidates. About 15 men have
been reporting daily for battery
.practice and Armstrong is hoping
to have his pitchers and catchers
in good shape by the time weather
conditions will permit the calling
of the whole squad.
Dr. Van Orman is directing the
laying out of the new diamond.
The home plate is to be moved
further back; part of the fence in
right field will be removed, greatly
bettering conditions in the outfield, and the infield will be
skinned, which should encourage
fast and accurate fielding.
At the first 'baseball meeting
both Coach Armstrong and Dr.
Van Orman emphasized the fact
that no favoritism would be shown
in picking the team. The squad
of 50 men will .be called out for
practice this week. Much competition is expected for the various
positions and the team picked for
the first game on March 26 will
be a strong one.

DR. EDWARD HULBURT TO ADDRESS SCIENCE CLUB.

Dr. Edward Hulburt will deliver a lecture on Wednesday,
March 9, in Room 110, M. E. Building, at 12.30 o'clock, on the "Application of the Vacuum Tube to
Wireless Telegraphy." Although
the subject is one which might be
made very technical, Dr. Hulburt
intends to make the talk as simple
as possible so that it may be understood by everyone.

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

CONSTRUCTIVE, NOT DESTRUCTIVE, CRITICISM NEEDED.

FOUNDED 1897.

The NEWS-LETTER is the students' publication at Hopkins, and
it attempts to present the opinions and ideas of the student
body. Whether or not it succeeds
in this attempt depends entirely
upon the support given it by the
student body. If it is "dead from
the neck up," as some intimate,
the fault rests not so much with
the editors as with the students
themselves.
We are always willing to receive criticism and suggestions,.
and are glad to voice any complaints of the students either
through our letter or editorial columns. If we make a mistake—
and not being infallible we naturally make many—come out frankly
and say so, and help us remedy our
defects.
, Don't join the crowd of perpetual knockers, who spend their
time joyfully tearing to pieces behind their backs every activity at
the university, but fail to give any
of these activities the benefit of
their superior knowledge and insight by active participation.
Any ass can kick a wagon to
pieces, but it takes a man to build
one.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 8, 1921
BACK UP THE DRAMATIC CLUB.

The Dramatic Club will present
"Arms and the Man" Friday night
at the Lyjic. For over six weeks
the members of the club have concentrated every effort to make the
play a success, and no amount of
time nor money has been spared
in coaching and rehearsing, and
in the provision of properties.
The play itself is one of Bernard Shaw's delightful comedies,
and is well worth presentation on
account of its exceptional merit.
In presenting the play at the
Lyric, the only available theater
in town, the club assumes a great
responsibility. It is up to every
loyal Hopkins man to help share
that responsibility by being present Friday night.
The prices of tickets range from
50 cents to $2.75, so that "being
broke" is no excuse for one's failure to appear, and we must remember that by being present—
whether sitting in box or gallery—
we help the club not only in
finances, but in morale.
We have all heard that it is
hard to play to an empty "house."
Let's help the cast do its best by
backing it up with a large and
enthusiastic audience.

LITERARY CLUB MEETS
Wiscott

Reads

Paper
France.

on

Anatole

At the regular meeting of the
Literary Club Mr. J. W. Wiscott
spoke on Anatole France and his
works. He stressed particularly
the relation of France to his contemporaries and his probable influence upon the future literature
of Europe.
The meeting was well attended
and the old-time verve and enthusiasm were very much in evidence. The discussion was preceded by a supper which has come
to be a permanent feature of the
club's program.
President Goetz outlined the
program of the club for the remainder of the year, and many
new members should be attracted.
- The next meeting will be held
on Friday, March 18, at the Johns
Hopkins Club, and a large attendance is expected.
ANOTHER CLUB FOR HOPKINS
The Spectacle Club of the Johns
Hopkins University announce its
instalment as a regular campus
organization. The object of this
society is to promote good-fellowship among the myopic. Meetings
are to be held every Thursday at
11.30 (while the uninitiated are at
the assembly). On meeting days
the members will wear dark
glasses to all classes. The names
of the organizers and neophytes
will be announced at graduation,
but until that-time the "men of the
smoked glasses" will remain incognito.

SCIENCE CLUB.
The Social Science Club has had
a very, eventful week. Last Monday, Dr. David McCabe of Princeton gave a highly entertaining
talk, during the course of which
he advocated more newspaper
publicity in industrial disputes.
He was of the opinion that an
enlightened public was of more
value than anything else in labor
disputes, and that if the public.
was kept informed by means of an
impartial press, neither capital
labor would step out of bounds.
He considered the editorial policy
of the New York Times prejudicial
to labor and alleged the suppression, or at least subordination of
news favorable to labor.
The club held a discussion meeting Friday afternoon and went
over Dr. McCabe's address in detail. R. K. Guggenheimer attempted to prove by quotations
from news articles and editorials
that the Times policy is absolutely impartial to both capital
and labor, and that while it rarely
supported labor in an industrial
dispute, at least, it gave both sides
of the question. The discussion
was intensely interesting and there
was a fairly large attendance.
Members of the club feel that they
are deriving great benefit from
their membership; leading thinkers have addressed the club and
the meetings are a real opportunity to hear the views of others
and to express your own.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 8, 1921
"ARMS AND THE MAN" TO
BE PRESENTED FRIDAY
AT LYRIC
Some Last Minute Changes Made in
Cast—Play Promises to Come
Up to Previous Performances of Club.

,

A large and enthusiastic audience is expected to attend the
performance at the Lyric this Friday night of George Bernard
Shaw's "Arms and the Man,"
which will be presented by the
Johns Hopkins Dramatic Club.
The play will represent the best
efforts of the club to put on a
play which will uphold the standards of Johns Hopkins in the dramatic line and should certainly
please the most discriminating
critic.
The cast will be:
Riana—Joseph Moran,'23.
Louka—Henry D. West, '23.
Catherine—E. S. Basford,'21.
The Man—Bartus Trew, '21.
Sergius—H. P. Brawner, '23.
Petkoff—D. S. Mossom, '21.
Nicola—Eli Frank, Jr., '22.
Officer of the Guards—Glover
Fallon, '23.
It has been found necessary to
make several changes in the cast
from that announced last week.
These have been effected without
much difficulty by changing Brawner's part, which was that of
Petkoff, the major in the Bulgarian army, and which he was
carrying off very well, to that of
Sergius. There was some hesitation about doing this at first, but
recent rehearsals have shown that
any doubt as to his ability to do
himself justice was unfounded
Mosson has been transferred from
the part of Nicola to that of Pet, koff and Eli Frank has taken his
old part.
Miss Walter, who has coached
the production, feels confident
that the cast will be entirely coordinated by Friday and that the
performance will be up to the
standard set by the club in "You
Never Can Tell" and "The Admirable Crichton."
The musical program will be
rendered .by the undergraduate
orchestra, under the direction of
"Mike" Bowers.

THE ARCADE TEA ROOM

A LETTER.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir—Why should we lose
our mental poise, cast reason to
the winds and work twice as hard?
The fact that the Goucher girls
are willing to work harder
throughout the year in order to
avoid an examination is no criterion that we should do the same.
If our editor would study this subject closely he would find that one
reason that.prompts them to study
hard each day is the fact that daily
grades and quizzes count more
Not so at
than examinations.
Hopkins, if you make the examination, nine times out of ten you
have made the'course.
Why should we• keep a large
mass of facts at our finger-tips
every day when they are of little
use until the examination? Why
keep our mental faculty saturated
with facts throughout the year
when a two days' review just before the examination will answer
the same purpose? What is the
objection to examinations as they
are given? Who is willing to put
in three hours a week of hard
study for four and a half months,
54 hours' mental exertion, when
12 hours the week before the examinations keep it fresher in our
minds during the examinations?
Why not leave well enough alone?
Let us follow the status quo—the
line of least resistance. I am not
advocating cramming, but he
among you who is innocent of this
(cramming), let him cast the first
stone.

The post of Plattsburg barracks
is practically in the city of Plattsburg; is directly on the shore of
Lake Champlain and is actually
closer to the railroad station than
most of the town.
The camp is located on the beautiful Lake Champlain that offers
fishing and swimming. Large
steamers provide delightful excursions to Burlington, Vt.; Fort
Ticonderago, Crown Point and
Whitehall. There are excellent
motor roads and rail connections
to the many mountain and lake resorts nearby and to the noted Ausable Chasm. A trolley line runs
from and through Plattsburgh
right by the post, past the Catholic Kummer School of America
to Hotel Champlain at Bluff Point.
Attention is being given to entertainment and amusement. A
baseball diamond is available.
The cavalry R. 0. T. C. camp will
be just across the Lake at Fort
Ethan Allen and games may be
arranged. There are two tennis
courts and the privilege of an 18hole golf course.

RUTGERS SWIMMERS WIN
INDIVIDUAL CHAMPIONSHIPS.
First in Six Out of Seven Events—
Rowland of Hopkins Captures
Breast Strokes—Hopkins
Second in Total Score.

Rutgers swimmers captured first
places in every event but one at
the Eastern Collegiate Swimming
Association'Individual Championships held at New Brunswick last
Saturday. The one event in which
they fell down was the breast
stroke, which was won by Daviage
Rowland, captain of the Hopkins
mermen.
Lehigh and Swarthmore, the two Other members of
the asociafion, did not enter complete teams and failed to carry off
very high honors.
The Hopkins team was handicapped by the absence of two of its
stars, Hall and Coady, who were
counted up to annex several
points, but who were unable to
take the trip.
The Baltimore Relay Team finished second to the Rutgers squad
in the first event, while the first
three places in the fancy dive were
taken, respectively, by representatives of Rutgers, Lehigh and
Swarthmore.
Hopkins failed to place in the
50-yard dash, which went to the
home team, with Lehigh third and
fourth. Reins of Hopkins finished
third in the back stroke, in which
Siebel broke the record formerly
held by Hall of Hopkins. Manager Gould of the Homewood aggregation pulled a second place in the
220-yard swim, and a little while
later finished fourth in the 100yard dash.
Rowland and Boliver of Hopkins captured first and fourth positions in the breast stroke, after
which Siebel won his third event
of the day by taking the 100-yard
dash.

Chapel Hill, N. C., will be the
scene of the annual contest of the
Southern Intercollegiate Oratorical League on March 11, according to Dr. George McKie,
chairman of the executive committee. C. I. T. Gould, Jr., the representative of Hopkins in this very
important contest, has taken as
his subject the problem of the exclusion of Japanese immigrants.
Since March 11 is also the date
set for the Adams Debate Contest,
Gould has resigned his place on
the Senior debating team in favor
of Burdelle Cannon, chosen as alternate in the tryouts. A new
alternate will be named shortly.

DR. WOOD GIVES LECTURE
ON VIOLET RAY
Large Body of Students Present.
Many Interesting Phenomena
Explained.

So attractive was the mere announcement of a lecture by Dr.
Robert W. Wood, one of Hopkins'
most famous scientists, on the subject with which his name is everywhere linked, that one of the largest crowds of the year besieged
the doors of the lecture-room in
the Mechanical Engineering Building, necessitating a division of the
audience into two relays. Dr.
Wood very kindly consented to
this plan, not objecting to the inconvenience of giving a continuous
performance a la movies.
Dr. Wood plunged immediately
into the explanation of how he had
utilized the hitherto unrelated
phenomena connected with the
viol-ray emanations f o r producing a highly valuable method
of invisible night signalling on a
practical engineering scale. In
clear, simple language he sketched
the theory and development of
the ultra-violet ray lamp and receiver used by our navy during the
war.
Before giving his audience a
chance to see for themselves the
weird effects of his invention, the
lecturer explained what would
happen. The _violet rays would
cause teeth and eyes to fluoresce,
and in the case of those close
enough to the lamp the skin and
nails would also shine.
Then the room lights were
turned down, and out of the darkness somewhere down in front
there danced and faded a beautiful blue light, weak and retiring
as a will o' the wisp at first, but
gradually increasing in steadiness
to the time when a soft blue haze
began to settle before the eyes of
the mystified observers. The nian
in the front row who turned away
from the lamp when the haze appeared only to see the teeth of his
friend leaping out at him like the
advertisement of a painless dentist may be pardoned if he dropped
his books. Indeed, if Dr. Wood
had not warned the assembly
ahead of time that the blue haze
was merely an effect of the fluorescing of the eyes under the violet
rays, many a man would have left
the hall.
After he had finished exhibiting
many of the peculiarities of his
pet, Dr. Wood allowed the men to
come down a few at a time to get.
a close view of the phenomena. It
was, indeed, a rare opportunity.
and no man who witnessed the
demonstration is liable to forget
it for a long time.

ELECTRICAL CLUB MAKES
INTERESTING CHANGE
IN WORK
Solutions of Current Problems Planned.
Melvin Fuld to Speak March
11 on Motor Troubles.

On Friday, February 25, Mr.
Wm. S. Weikle gave the Hopkins
Electrical Club a very interesting
illustrated lecture on "The Development of Low Head Plants." He
told of the rehabilitation of many
old power plants, the efficiency being greatly increased by the installation of new equipment in conjunction with the water turbines
already operating. A general discussion followed the talk and Mr.
Weikle answered questions pertaining to his subject.
The club has set aside part of
the time of its meetings for the
solution of current problems arising in the electrical engineering
course and it is believed that this
feature of the program will prove
very beneficial to all the members.
Difficulties resulting from the previous week's work will be cleared
up and advance theory explained,
so that those attending the meetings will be at an advantage in
that they will be familiar with
the new work as it is taken up.
The organization, though only
a few weeks old, has made rapid
progress, its membership now, including some 25 seniors, juniors,
and a few sophomores.
The next meeting will be held
on Friday, March 11, when Mr.
Melvin Fuld will talk on "Minor
Motor Troubles and Their Remedies." An interesting program
is promised and visitors are always welcome.

PICTURES FOR THIS WEEK.

The Hullabaloo staff photographer will take pictures of Seniors
at the Barn today.(Tuesday) from
12.30 to 2.00 P. M. This is the last
day on which these snapshots may
be taken. This is also the last
week in which individual Senior
pictures can be taken at Yatt's
studio, 313 North Charles street.
The schedule of groups for the
week is as follows:

With the opening game only
three weeks off Coach Armstrong
has been busily engaged during
the past week with the battery
candidates. About 15 men have
been reporting daily for battery
.practice and Armstrong is hoping
to have his pitchers and catchers
in good shape by the time weather
conditions will permit the calling
of the whole squad.
Dr. Van Orman is directing the
laying out of the new diamond.
The home plate is to be moved
further back; part of the fence in
right field will be removed, greatly
bettering conditions in the outfield, and the infield will be
skinned, which should encourage
fast and accurate fielding.
At the first 'baseball meeting
both Coach Armstrong and Dr.
Van Orman emphasized the fact
that no favoritism would be shown
in picking the team. The squad
of 50 men will .be called out for
practice this week. Much competition is expected for the various
positions and the team picked for
the first game on March 26 will
be a strong one.

DR. EDWARD HULBURT TO ADDRESS SCIENCE CLUB.

Dr. Edward Hulburt will deliver a lecture on Wednesday,
March 9, in Room 110, M. E. Building, at 12.30 o'clock, on the "Application of the Vacuum Tube to
Wireless Telegraphy." Although
the subject is one which might be
made very technical, Dr. Hulburt
intends to make the talk as simple
as possible so that it may be understood by everyone.

CONSTRUCTIVE, NOT DESTRUCTIVE, CRITICISM NEEDED.

FOUNDED 1897.

The NEWS-LETTER is the students' publication at Hopkins, and
it attempts to present the opinions and ideas of the student
body. Whether or not it succeeds
in this attempt depends entirely
upon the support given it by the
student body. If it is "dead from
the neck up," as some intimate,
the fault rests not so much with
the editors as with the students
themselves.
We are always willing to receive criticism and suggestions,.
and are glad to voice any complaints of the students either
through our letter or editorial columns. If we make a mistake—
and not being infallible we naturally make many—come out frankly
and say so, and help us remedy our
defects.
, Don't join the crowd of perpetual knockers, who spend their
time joyfully tearing to pieces behind their backs every activity at
the university, but fail to give any
of these activities the benefit of
their superior knowledge and insight by active participation.
Any ass can kick a wagon to
pieces, but it takes a man to build
one.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 8, 1921
BACK UP THE DRAMATIC CLUB.

The Dramatic Club will present
"Arms and the Man" Friday night
at the Lyjic. For over six weeks
the members of the club have concentrated every effort to make the
play a success, and no amount of
time nor money has been spared
in coaching and rehearsing, and
in the provision of properties.
The play itself is one of Bernard Shaw's delightful comedies,
and is well worth presentation on
account of its exceptional merit.
In presenting the play at the
Lyric, the only available theater
in town, the club assumes a great
responsibility. It is up to every
loyal Hopkins man to help share
that responsibility by being present Friday night.
The prices of tickets range from
50 cents to $2.75, so that "being
broke" is no excuse for one's failure to appear, and we must remember that by being present—
whether sitting in box or gallery—
we help the club not only in
finances, but in morale.
We have all heard that it is
hard to play to an empty "house."
Let's help the cast do its best by
backing it up with a large and
enthusiastic audience.

LITERARY CLUB MEETS
Wiscott

Reads

Paper
France.

on

Anatole

At the regular meeting of the
Literary Club Mr. J. W. Wiscott
spoke on Anatole France and his
works. He stressed particularly
the relation of France to his contemporaries and his probable influence upon the future literature
of Europe.
The meeting was well attended
and the old-time verve and enthusiasm were very much in evidence. The discussion was preceded by a supper which has come
to be a permanent feature of the
club's program.
President Goetz outlined the
program of the club for the remainder of the year, and many
new members should be attracted.
- The next meeting will be held
on Friday, March 18, at the Johns
Hopkins Club, and a large attendance is expected.
ANOTHER CLUB FOR HOPKINS
The Spectacle Club of the Johns
Hopkins University announce its
instalment as a regular campus
organization. The object of this
society is to promote good-fellowship among the myopic. Meetings
are to be held every Thursday at
11.30 (while the uninitiated are at
the assembly). On meeting days
the members will wear dark
glasses to all classes. The names
of the organizers and neophytes
will be announced at graduation,
but until that-time the "men of the
smoked glasses" will remain incognito.

The Social Science Club has had
a very, eventful week. Last Monday, Dr. David McCabe of Princeton gave a highly entertaining
talk, during the course of which
he advocated more newspaper
publicity in industrial disputes.
He was of the opinion that an
enlightened public was of more
value than anything else in labor
disputes, and that if the public.
was kept informed by means of an
impartial press, neither capital
labor would step out of bounds.
He considered the editorial policy
of the New York Times prejudicial
to labor and alleged the suppression, or at least subordination of
news favorable to labor.
The club held a discussion meeting Friday afternoon and went
over Dr. McCabe's address in detail. R. K. Guggenheimer attempted to prove by quotations
from news articles and editorials
that the Times policy is absolutely impartial to both capital
and labor, and that while it rarely
supported labor in an industrial
dispute, at least, it gave both sides
of the question. The discussion
was intensely interesting and there
was a fairly large attendance.
Members of the club feel that they
are deriving great benefit from
their membership; leading thinkers have addressed the club and
the meetings are a real opportunity to hear the views of others
and to express your own.

knee-control limousine. Those Medics.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 8, 1921
"ARMS AND THE MAN" TO
BE PRESENTED FRIDAY
AT LYRIC
Some Last Minute Changes Made in
Cast—Play Promises to Come
Up to Previous Performances of Club.

,

A large and enthusiastic audience is expected to attend the
performance at the Lyric this Friday night of George Bernard
Shaw's "Arms and the Man,"
which will be presented by the
Johns Hopkins Dramatic Club.
The play will represent the best
efforts of the club to put on a
play which will uphold the standards of Johns Hopkins in the dramatic line and should certainly
please the most discriminating
critic.
The cast will be:
Riana—Joseph Moran,'23.
Louka—Henry D. West, '23.
Catherine—E. S. Basford,'21.
The Man—Bartus Trew, '21.
Sergius—H. P. Brawner, '23.
Petkoff—D. S. Mossom, '21.
Nicola—Eli Frank, Jr., '22.
Officer of the Guards—Glover
Fallon, '23.
It has been found necessary to
make several changes in the cast
from that announced last week.
These have been effected without
much difficulty by changing Brawner's part, which was that of
Petkoff, the major in the Bulgarian army, and which he was
carrying off very well, to that of
Sergius. There was some hesitation about doing this at first, but
recent rehearsals have shown that
any doubt as to his ability to do
himself justice was unfounded
Mosson has been transferred from
the part of Nicola to that of Pet, koff and Eli Frank has taken his
old part.
Miss Walter, who has coached
the production, feels confident
that the cast will be entirely coordinated by Friday and that the
performance will be up to the
standard set by the club in "You
Never Can Tell" and "The Admirable Crichton."
The musical program will be
rendered .by the undergraduate
orchestra, under the direction of
"Mike" Bowers.

THE ARCADE TEA ROOM

A LETTER.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir—Why should we lose
our mental poise, cast reason to
the winds and work twice as hard?
The fact that the Goucher girls
are willing to work harder
throughout the year in order to
avoid an examination is no criterion that we should do the same.
If our editor would study this subject closely he would find that one
reason that.prompts them to study
hard each day is the fact that daily
grades and quizzes count more
Not so at
than examinations.
Hopkins, if you make the examination, nine times out of ten you
have made the'course.
Why should we• keep a large
mass of facts at our finger-tips
every day when they are of little
use until the examination? Why
keep our mental faculty saturated
with facts throughout the year
when a two days' review just before the examination will answer
the same purpose? What is the
objection to examinations as they
are given? Who is willing to put
in three hours a week of hard
study for four and a half months,
54 hours' mental exertion, when
12 hours the week before the examinations keep it fresher in our
minds during the examinations?
Why not leave well enough alone?
Let us follow the status quo—the
line of least resistance. I am not
advocating cramming, but he
among you who is innocent of this
(cramming), let him cast the first
stone.

The post of Plattsburg barracks
is practically in the city of Plattsburg; is directly on the shore of
Lake Champlain and is actually
closer to the railroad station than
most of the town.
The camp is located on the beautiful Lake Champlain that offers
fishing and swimming. Large
steamers provide delightful excursions to Burlington, Vt.; Fort
Ticonderago, Crown Point and
Whitehall. There are excellent
motor roads and rail connections
to the many mountain and lake resorts nearby and to the noted Ausable Chasm. A trolley line runs
from and through Plattsburgh
right by the post, past the Catholic Kummer School of America
to Hotel Champlain at Bluff Point.
Attention is being given to entertainment and amusement. A
baseball diamond is available.
The cavalry R. 0. T. C. camp will
be just across the Lake at Fort
Ethan Allen and games may be
arranged. There are two tennis
courts and the privilege of an 18hole golf course.

RUTGERS SWIMMERS WIN
INDIVIDUAL CHAMPIONSHIPS.
First in Six Out of Seven Events—
Rowland of Hopkins Captures
Breast Strokes—Hopkins
Second in Total Score.

Rutgers swimmers captured first
places in every event but one at
the Eastern Collegiate Swimming
Association'Individual Championships held at New Brunswick last
Saturday. The one event in which
they fell down was the breast
stroke, which was won by Daviage
Rowland, captain of the Hopkins
mermen.
Lehigh and Swarthmore, the two Other members of
the asociafion, did not enter complete teams and failed to carry off
very high honors.
The Hopkins team was handicapped by the absence of two of its
stars, Hall and Coady, who were
counted up to annex several
points, but who were unable to
take the trip.
The Baltimore Relay Team finished second to the Rutgers squad
in the first event, while the first
three places in the fancy dive were
taken, respectively, by representatives of Rutgers, Lehigh and
Swarthmore.
Hopkins failed to place in the
50-yard dash, which went to the
home team, with Lehigh third and
fourth. Reins of Hopkins finished
third in the back stroke, in which
Siebel broke the record formerly
held by Hall of Hopkins. Manager Gould of the Homewood aggregation pulled a second place in the
220-yard swim, and a little while
later finished fourth in the 100yard dash.
Rowland and Boliver of Hopkins captured first and fourth positions in the breast stroke, after
which Siebel won his third event
of the day by taking the 100-yard
dash.

of Burdelle Cannon, chosen as alternate in the tryouts. A new
alternate will be named shortly.
